description: From Middle English brinie, burne (whence also, without metathesis, obsolete English brinie), from Old Norse brynja. Cognates include Old English byrne, Gothic ğŒ±ğ‚ğŒ¿ğŒ½ğŒ¾ğ‰ (brunjÅ) (whence Old Church Slavonic Ğ±Ñ€ÑŠĞ½Ñ© (brÅ­njÄ™)), German BrÃ¼nne, French broigne.

entries.meaning: (historical) A short chain mail shirt, covering from the upper arms to the upper thighs.
examples: Unferth stood beside him, his huge arms folded on his byrnie.
